summary.topic: welcome to dmw class 6; today, we're talking about building your personal brand
summary.summary: okay welcome to dmw class 6 today we're talking about building your personal brand and i've got three tips for you

summary.topic: three main goals: create a banger bio, know what to post, and craft your voice
summary.summary: by the end of this lecture, you'll leave with a killer bio for social media, know what to post consistently, and start honing your unique voice. here's why bios matter: imagine this...

summary.topic: importance of bios: visualize meeting someone new and explaining what you do
summary.summary: you're at a party meeting new people and get the usual questions like "what do you do?" just respond with "delusion is the solution" followed by whatever quirky project or interest you have, like building chesky or saying you're walking along the pathless path. keep it intriguing and vague to spark curiosity.

summary.topic: everyone laughs at the absurdity of confusing bios
summary.summary: discovered that everyone was laughing and roasting in good nature, realizing something needs to change. being on a social platform means you'll meet new people and should imagine yourself in their shoes.

summary.topic: being on social platforms means meeting new people frequently
summary.summary: you're going to meet new people daily, sometimes hourly, or even by the minute. if something blows up, it could be every second. make sure you help them.

summary.topic: aim to help others understand you quickly and clearly
summary.summary: to understand you so here are some accounts i like for their simplicity. sebastian, a graphic designer, is one of them. check out his work.

summary.topic: keep bios simple: examples include sebastian (graphic designer) and shan wasabi (music producer)
summary.summary: graphic designer open for commissions, and his IG has awesome images. sebastian is easy to contact. shan wasabi is a music producer – just check his spotify for music. also, listen to this banger podcast.

summary.topic: example podcast bio: "learn from history's greatest entrepreneurs every week"
summary.summary: learn from history's greatest entrepreneurs every week. i read a biography of an entrepreneur and share insights; 340 down, a thousand to go. david sra does a podcast on every entrepreneur you can think of. if you don't follow dingo's twitter, you definitely should.

summary.topic: duolingo's clear bio: "free language education for the world"
summary.summary: study this twitter account; let's keep it simple: free language education for the world, available on android, ios, and the web. super clear, right? after reviewing many of your bios, here's the advice: this is not the place to be creative. braden, please delete "delusion is the solution."

summary.topic: avoid overly creative bios; keep it straightforward
summary.summary: others you know walking along the pathless path. let's switch it up, keep it clear, like these examples, and keep it really short.

summary.topic: clear and concise bios make it easier to engage with you
summary.summary: can anticipate what many of you are going to think, uh it's just like you're more complex than that, right? why did you put delusion is a solution? um, in september, I felt lost with no directions and put I'm delusional on my FL. you're trying to capture something complex about yourself, but now as you build something new, your socials change too. you probably expect simplified versions in conversations, right?

summary.topic: good bios make people want to learn more about you and your work
summary.summary: if this intrigues you, you'll start asking more questions. let's take two: we're meeting new people again. how many of you know what a design document is? design mode equals on. i'm gonna blow your mind.

summary.topic: use basic design tools to edit and refine your bios
summary.summary: right-click, inspect, go to console, type `document.designMode = "on"`, and you can directly edit the page. use this trick to draft bios, tweets, or posts. suggestions: change "hits to a making a film school" to "building a school to teach anyone how to make better films." what's next?

summary.topic: craft bios that invite curiosity and further questions
summary.summary: this profile grabs your attention, leading you to check out the school or decide your next steps. once hooked, you'll scroll down and check out the feed. pretty straightforward.

summary.topic: congruency between your bio and what you post is key
summary.summary: everything you put online can be designed, which is why i'm building a school to teach anyone to make better films. some of you already have good ones, like cats on twitter or music producer tracks on spotify. niti is clear about navigating brown girl trauma on her ig.

summary.topic: consistency across platforms helps people understand who you are
summary.summary: adapt to a platform but stay consistent so people know who you are and what you're about across all platforms. this will help you figure out what you should be posting.

summary.topic: post about your work frequently to build an audience
summary.summary: you should definitely be posting more about your work on your socials. building an audience now is crucial, even during sf2. your project might change, but having a dedicated audience will support you through the journey. think of it like meeting new people at a party and introducing yourself as, "hi, i'm cat, i produce music."

summary.topic: clarity in bios leads to more engaging conversations, both online and offline
summary.summary: rohad is building a film school and if introduced, you'd naturally ask questions like "why are you building a film school?", "where is it?", "what kind of films?", and "how can I join?". cat, who quit her tech job to make music full-time, answers these types of questions upfront on her feed.

summary.topic: example of good engagement: cats on twitter who clearly states their work
summary.summary: let's look at the anticipated questions. you don't mind me roasting you a bit, right Road? let's look at rhead. oh, pretty good, RAB just posted this.

summary.topic: anticipate questions people might ask based on your bio
summary.summary: posted this on march 4th: learn anything about filmmaking by hitting my dms. building a film school teaches better filmmaking, creating connections helps too. bio can connect your entire feed. once the bio is set, post about getting into film, entering film school, making better films, and the process of building a film school.

summary.topic: use your feed to answer common questions and provide more context
summary.summary: we need to improve our execution, and i'm going to show you how by delving into the archives. raising credibility is key, so consider who else you've taught and your background. let's focus on building rib's credibility.

summary.topic: differentiate yourself by having clear, well-defined posts
rohan's example: building credibility through frequent and relevant posts
summary.summary: building credibility involves follower counts and engagement levels on posts, alongside testimonials for social proof. don't assume large follower numbers alone build credibility; high followers but low engagement can suggest issues like bots.

summary.topic: showcase your expertise or learning process in your posts
summary.summary: we're at a place where people build cool [__] and that's what you'll see on our feed—either people building, learning, or teaching how to build cool [__]. we reviewed an AI reality TV account and suggested making the thumbnails clearer to instantly improve the account. the main feedback was to make it obvious what AI reality TV is through better visuals.

summary.topic: maintain consistent branding and thematic focus in your posts
summary.summary: keeping your feed consistent is crucial. improve your bio by removing unnecessary information; focus on clarity. ensure your feed reflects who you are, like showcasing your work if you're a music producer. be the friend who hypes up your own content, and take time to hone your voice, as Duolingo did with its unique, engaging posts.

summary.topic: errors and learning experiences are part of the journey
summary.summary: accountable hey I shipped this, the whole team agreed. it's a fake phone thing. did you get the [__] out local host make?

summary.topic: it's okay to iterate and find out what works for your audience
summary.summary: sure to ship shrooms later, bro. there were times when we didn't know what we were shipping, and it took us a while to figure things out and start shipping coherently. i'm showing this to illustrate our process and not just to roast you.

summary.topic: use personal experiences and transparent posts to connect with your audience
summary.summary: engagement and fan-building were great when we started out being super clear. now, moving to youtube, we're starting from scratch again, and engagement isn't as good. being clear helps, and sharing learnings or expertise on platforms like twitter and instagram daily can boost engagement.

summary.topic: engaging posts often contain clear, truthful, and relatable content
summary.summary: farza tweets about what he feels he's an expert in and emphasizes the importance of truth in posts, highlighting authenticity. sharing honest confessions can gain acceptance, as seen in farza's posts where he admits mistakes. being relatable by acknowledging challenges resonates well with the audience. forget complicated storytelling tips—simple honesty works best.

summary.topic: three takeaways: clear bio, consistent posts, and authenticity in voice
summary.summary: how do i make my cold emails really good? just start doing these three things: focus on storytelling, keep it concise, and personalize each message. do this, and everything else will fall into place.

summary.topic: additional help will be provided in crafting stories and handling cold emails
summary.summary: maybe i can give you this. that topic is a whole lecture in itself. i wanted to pack it in but i feel like it becomes too much.

summary.topic: the next lecture might cover storytelling in more depth
summary.summary: we could have two dmws next week if you want. any questions?
